member.name: P:ILNumerics.Drawing.Plotting.BarPlot.Draw3D
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the bars are rendered as 3D objects.

remarks.para: Boolean parameter defining the 3D style of the bars. If set to true, each bar will be drawn as 3D cube, otherwise, as flat rectangle.
By default, is false.

member.name: P:ILNumerics.Drawing.Plotting.BarPlot.Horizontal
member.summary: Get or sets the rendering style of the bar plot.

remarks.para: Boolean parameter defining the rendering style of the bars. If set to true, each bar will be drawn horizontally, otherwise vertically (default).

member.name: P:ILNumerics.Drawing.Plotting.BarPlot.BarWidth
member.summary: Gets or sets the bar width.

remarks.para: defines the width of each bar as a scalar value from 0 to 1. Default is 0.8f, that means the bar width is 80% of the space from the previous bar to the next bar. If set to 1.0f, each bar touch one another.

member.exception: If value set to negative value or value is larger than 1.

member.name: P:ILNumerics.Drawing.Plotting.BarPlot.Padding
member.summary: Gets or sets the distance between groups.

remarks.para: Parameter must be a scalar value from 0.0f to 1.0f. Padding is available only if is set to grouped. Default value is 0.2f, that means that, bar groups are distanced at 20% from maximal .

member.exception: If bar width value is negative or more than 1.0f

member.name: P:ILNumerics.Drawing.Plotting.BarPlot.UseLighting
member.summary: Determines, if the bar plot utilizes lighting. Default: Auto (null, light for flat bar plots, no light for 3D bar plots)

remarks.para: By default, utilizes lighting for 2D bars only. Light gives the bars a highlighting effect and improves the niceness of the bars. However, since focusses on fast rendering, such lighting brings certain limitations for sophisticated 3D bars (). In order to achieve good performance, such 3D bars are not optimized for perfect lighting. Hence, lighting is disabled for in 3D mode by default.
One can overwrite this default behavior by assigning an explicit boolean value to . This affects all bars, regardless if rendered in 2D or 3D mode.
See for creating bar plots which focus on nice colors and lighting in 3D mode.

member.summary: Creates a new Bar plot based on provided values .
member.param: Vector or matrix defines bar values to draw.
[Optional] Vector or matrix defines positions of bars to draw. If not set, bars positions will be placed(or grouped) on range [1,2,..,n].
[Optional] Tag identifying the plot in the scene
[Optional] Bar plot style specified by one of the values from BarPlotStyle. Default:
[Optional] Color of the bar border, default: Color.Black, if border color is set, then defined border color will be assigned to all bar groups.
[Optional] Fill color of the bar, default: auto (sequencing individual colors via NextColors provider), if fill color is set, then defined fill color will be assigned to all bar groups.
[Optional] Bar border width, default: 1px
[Optional] Line style, default: solid
[Optional] Bar width specified as single value from 0 to 1. Default: 0.8f. If is 1.0f, then the bars within a group touch one another
[Optional] Base value specified as scalar value. Default: 0.0f, see also property.
[Optional] Drawing style parameter. If set to true, each bar will be drawn as 3D bar, otherwise, as flat rectangles. Default:false.
[Optional] Drawing style parameter. If set to true, all bars will be drawn horizontally, otherwise, vertically. Default:false.

remarks.para: If is specified as vector, BarPlot draws one group of bars. If is specified as matrix [m x n], BarPlot draws m groups of n bars.
The following optional parameters: , , , and could be changed by using public properties.
If defined as , it takes effect only if is set to true.

member.exception: If is null or has more than 2 dimensions.
If is empty or has more than 2 dimensions.
If has different shape than See: for allowed shapes definitions.

member.name: M:ILNumerics.Drawing.Plotting.BarPlot.SetGroupColor(System.Int32,System.Nullable{System.Drawing.Color},System.Nullable{System.Drawing.Color})
member.summary: Method sets custom border and fill color to group of bars by .
member.param: Group ID number[0,n]. An integer value defines a group ID to assign a custom color.
[Optional] Border color of the bar group selected by , default: null - skip changing border color.
[Optional] Fill color of the bar group selected by , default: null - skip changing fill color.

remarks.para: If bar plot is defined with vector array, SetGroupColor, sets a color to all bars. ID must be equal 0.
If bar plot is defined with matrix, SetGroupColor, sets a color to whole bar group, defined by .

member.exception: If selected not exists.

member.name: P:ILNumerics.Drawing.Plotting.BoxPlot.FillArea
member.summary: Provides a reference to the fill areas of box plots

remarks.para: The property allows direct access to the triangles strip, partly defining BoxPlot. It allows all configurations valid for general shapes, including access to the rendering , as well as the and buffers, the solid property, all mouse events and light configuration.

High level functions of modify internal data and therefore also the internal triangles strip shape. Since provides direct access to this shape, users must take care of potentially conflicting changes to the , caused by manual changed and by changes due to the function.

member.name: P:ILNumerics.Drawing.Plotting.Candlestick.BullShadow
member.summary: Provides a reference to the lines of the shadows of bull candlesticks

remarks.para: The property allows direct access to the line plot, partly defining CandleStick. It allows all configurations valid for general shapes, including access to the rendering , as well as the and buffers, the solid property, all mouse events and light configuration.

High level functions of modify internal data and therefore also the internal line plot shape. Since provides direct access to this shape, users must take care of potentially conflicting changes to the , caused by manual changed and by changes due to the function.

member.name: T:ILNumerics.Drawing.Plotting.FastSurface
member.summary: A simple, yet rich surface object, focussing on performance of rendering and updates.
member.remarks:
The plot object offers a performant way of displaying 3 or 4 dimensional data on a 2 or 3 dimensional grid, involving the height (Z) coordinates and / or the colors of the grid tiles. Efficient updates to the data (including the shape, individual coordinates and/or individual colors) are possible.
In difference to , is not able to handle transparency and does not maintain a wireframe.
objects are created empty and afterwards configured solely by the method.

member.name: P:ILNumerics.Drawing.Plotting.FastSurface.Fill
member.summary: Gives a reference to the triangle strip shape of the surface fill (readonly, the shape itself is mutable).

remarks.para: The property allows direct access to the triangles shape realizing the filled area of the surface. It allows all configurations valid for general shapes, including access to the rendering , like the and buffers, the solid property, all mouse events and light configuration.

High level functions of modify the internal data and the internal triangle strip shape. Therefore and since gives direct access to this shape, users must take care of potentially conflicting changes to the , caused by manual changed and by changes due to the "/> function.

example.para: Create a simple fast surface and enable lighting on the fill.

member.name: M:ILNumerics.Drawing.Plotting.FastSurface.#ctor(System.Object)
member.summary: Fast surface constructor, creates an empty surface. Use on the created object for configuration!
member.param: [Optional] Tag used to identify the object in the scene. Default: ('FastSurface').

member.summary: Configure/ change/ update the surface data.
member.param: [Optional] X coordinates. Grid vector or meshgrid result. Default (null): do not change.
[Optional] Y coordinates. Grid vector or meshgrid result. Default (null): do not change.
[Optional] Matrix of new Z values. Default (null): do not change.
[Optional] Matrix with new color data for mapping with . Default (null): do not change.
[Optional] Colormap used to map C or Z values to rendering colors. Default (null): .
[Optional] Minimum point of the new bounding box. Default (null): compute from given arguments.
[Optional] Maximum point of the new bounding box. Default (null): compute from given arguments.
[Optional] Range of values for deriving the colors from the colormap. Default (null): min / max value from / .
[Optional] [Experimental phase] Set this parameter to true and too large data will be downscaled according to the current view. Default: false

remarks.para: All parameters are optional.

The grid size and position is determined by (in this order): Z, X, Y or C parameters. If none of these parameters are given, the existing grid of the surface will not change. If any of Z, X, Y, and/or C are provided, they must all have the same size. Alternatively, either one of them can be a scalar. The scalar value will be used for all grid points in this case.

Either of , , or must be given at least once in order to specify the intial shape of the surface. The minimal grid size of a surface is 2 x 2, hence the matrices provided must have not less than 2 elements in columns and rows.
The size of the grid can be redefined at any time by providing different , , or parameters.

and can be grid vectors with the coordinates in the corresponding dimension of the grid points. Alternatively, they can be the output of , i.e.: the X and Y coordinates of all grid points. In this case, the given array must match the shape of and/or respectively.

As a special case, either of the size defining parameters , , or can be a scalar. Its value is then used for all grid points. In this case, the size of the grid must have been specified already (by a former call to Update()) or must be defined by other, non-scalar parameters.
Surfaces require at least 2 rows and 2 columns.
Changing the grid size will set any non-specified parameter to its default values.

The and properties can optionally be used to save the computational efforts of determining the new bounding box limits after the update was completed. If the nature of the new data is sufficiently known, providing these limits will further speed up the refreshing of the surface.
Calling this method potentially triggers PropertyChanged events on the following properties: , , , , .

Auto Downscaling: This option is still in the experimental phase. Only by setting the input parameter to true, this option is selected. The default value is set to false, this way the original version of FastSurface() is applied.

member.exception: if the shape of any positional parameter provided or C is invalid / not consistent with other parameters. Inspect exception message for details.

summary.para: This class creates a smoothed surface out of scattered data points. It allows to control the , the surface (extrapolation area around the given points) and the .

Out of the provided scattered data points computes a regular grid via kriging interpolation. In a postprocessing step the grid is smoothed by efficient low-pass filtering (via fast fourier transform).
can be used like a regular ILNumerics visualization object, directly as a child of Scene.Camera. Or, one may add it to a plot cube to get labeling and all common interactive options.

is composed out of a regular and an shape. The displays the smoothed grid and the display the scattered data points. Both objects are accessible by the and properties, respectively. They can be configured in arbitrary ways, including changing the colormap for the surface, the colors and size of the points, configuring the wireframe, enabling / disabling and configuring light effects.

Kriging interpolation comes with a memory requirement of O(N). This means, if your input data (point cloud) has n points it will internaly try to create a matrix of n x n single precision floating point values. Make sure to target x64 and/or to limit the number of data points accordingly to allow this memory even for large data.

Another aspect of kriging is its global interpolation method: all data points are considered for each new interpolated value. So, the original points should be 'well suited'. This class together with the Kriging interpolators will perform multiple checks on the data and attempt to remove any disturbing artefacts. But you can help by making sure to provide 'clean' data: don't provide data points laying too close to each other and remove any outliers!
Kriging interpolation is described in more detail here: . Note, that this class depends on the ILNumerics.Toolboxes.Interpolation module. (But a license is required for the Drawing2 toolbox only.)

member.summary: Size (width, height) of the surface edge outside the specified data points. Exrapolation is performed here. Default: 0.1, 0.1

member.name: P:ILNumerics.Drawing.Plotting.SmoothSurface.Resolution
member.summary: Number of interpolated points along X and Y. Default: 150 x 150.

member.name: P:ILNumerics.Drawing.Plotting.SmoothSurface.SmoothingFactor
member.summary: Determins the degree of smoothing applied to the resulting surface. Number of neighboring grid samples to be included into the computation of a final data point. Default: 0 (no smoothing).

remarks.para: The value for must be positive and in range [0... Min(m_resolution.Width, m_resolution.Height)]. If the provided new value is outside of that range it is automatically adjusted to fit into the allowed range and a message is written into the log.

In a setup where the surface is dynamically updates with new values for one may notices a slight 'jump' of the interpolated surface along the XY diagonal by an offset of ~1 grid element. This effect is caused by the moving average filter. It depends on the current value of . The filter is symmetric only for even values of . Uneven values cause a slight shift of the interpolated region. This effect can be avoided by providing even values to the property only. This corresponding example demonstrates this method: .

Access to this shape must be limited to the configuration of visual properties! Do not change the Positions of the points! This would bring the into inconsistent state! In order to change the orinial points a new must be created.

member.name: M:ILNumerics.Drawing.Plotting.SmoothSurface.#ctor(ILNumerics.InArray{System.Double},ILNumerics.InArray{System.Double},System.Boolean,System.Nullable{System.Drawing.SizeF},System.Nullable{System.Drawing.Size},System.UInt32)
member.summary: Creates a new plot.
member.param: Matrix with 2 rows. Each colum stores the X and Y coordinates of a single data point at arbitrary position.
Z values for all points given in . Vector of length .S[1].
[Optional] Whether to mark the original point in the surface. True: show points. Default: true.

[Optional] Specify the fraction of the overall width / height the resulting surface is extended (by extrapolation) to reach over the minimum / maximum specified points. Default: 0.1 of the specified width / heigth.
[Optional] Number of new data points for the interpolation grid. Default: 150 x 150 points.
[Optional] Averaging factor. Number of neighboring samples to consider when applying an moving average filter in the post processing. Default: 0 (no smoothing).

remarks.para: A value of 0.5 for 'Margin.Width' means: adds half of the actual width (as specified by to the left and the right end of the surface width and computes values for this area by extrapolation. Default value is 0.1. The same scheme applies for .Height correspondingly.

If you want the resulting interpolated data to look smoother by decreasing, let's say: peaks coming from measurement errors, there are two options to achieve this:
Use fewer interpolated data points. Decrease to compute fewer points in both directions (width / height).
Use the argument, specifying a higher value. The default value '0' performs no smoothing. Higher values result in more smooth surfaces.
Note, that both control options depend on each other! In order to find an optimal setting it is recommended to ...

1) determine a which leads to a grid resolution with small enough tiles. In a setup with too small resolution tiles can become too large so that the surface looks 'edgy'. Increase the parameter (here or later on the created object) until the tiles have a appropriate size.
2) Now find a good for the selected resolution. Larger resolution surfaces require a higher value for in order to achieve the same smoothness of the result.

member.summary: Default constructor.
This constructor defines a stacked area plot on the basis of the arrays and .
member.param: X is a [1 x n] row vector. It contains the x coordinates for the area plots.

Y is a [m x n] matrix. For the stacked area plot, this matrix contains vertical distances. Here, each row is added to the previous row to create the stacked area plot. For the layered area plot, this matrix contains the vertical positions for each area plot.
If set to true, a layered area plot is created, default: false.
[optional] Only for LayeredAreaPlots: Spacing defines the distance between the area plots on the Z-axis, default: 0.05.
[optional] Colormap is used to map the positions of the area plots on the Z-axis. The Z positions are computed based on the input parameter . Default: Colormaps.ILNumerics.
[optional] Line color, default: Colormaps.ILNumerics.
[optional] Line Width, default: 1px.
[optional] Fill Color.
[optional] Column vector that contains alpha values between 0 and 255 for each area plot. 0 indicates full transparency, while 255 represents no transparency.
[optional] identifies StackedAreaPlot in the scene graph, default: StackedAreaPlot.

remarks.para: Each row of and describes a single area plot. Hence, and must have a matching number of rows.

By default, both the fill areas and borders of the area plot are colored in on the basis of a colormap. By assigning a value to all lines receive the same color. The same applies to . Use to better distinguish the area plots.

member.param: X is a [1 x n] row vector. It contains the x coordinates for the area plots.

Y is a [m x n] matrix. For the stacked area plot, this matrix contains vertical distances. Here, each row is added to the previous row to create the stacked area plot. For the layered area plot, this matrix contains the vertical positions for each area plot.
If set to true, a layered area plot is created, default: false.
[optional] Only for LayeredAreaPlots: Spacing defines the distance between the area plots on the Z-axis, default: 0.05.
[optional] Colormap is used to map the positions of the area plots on the Z-axis. The Z positions are computed based on the input parameter . Default: Colormaps.ILNumerics.
[optional] Line color, default: Colormaps.ILNumerics.
[optional] Line Width, default: 1px.
[optional] Fill Color.
[optional] Column vector that contains alpha values between 0 and 255 for each area plot. 0 indicates full transparency, while 255 represents no transparency.
[optional] identifies StackedAreaPlot in the scene graph, default: StackedAreaPlot.

remarks.para: Each row of and describes a single area plot. Hence, and must have a matching number of rows.

By default, both the fill areas and borders of the area plot are colored in on the basis of a colormap. By assigning a value to all lines receive the same color. The same applies to . Use to better distinguish the area plots.
